content.text: (a) (i) Move the 1.50 N load to a distance \(d=40.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) from the 0.0 cm end of the ruler
Raise or lower one clamp slightly, if necessary, so that the metre ruler is as near to horizontal as possible
Read the value \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\) on force meter X and the value \(F_{\mathrm{Y}}\) on force meter Y
Calculate a value \(W_{\mathrm{X}}\) using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{X}}=F_{\mathrm{X}}+F_{\mathrm{Y}}-k\), where \(k=1.50 \mathrm{~N}\)
(ii) Briefly describe how to check that the ruler is horizontal before taking the reading. You may draw a diagram
(b) Move the 1.50 N load to a distance \(d=10.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) from the 0.0 cm end of the ruler. Ensure that the metre ruler is as near to horizontal as possible
Read, and record in Table 1.1, the value \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\) on force meter X
Repeat this procedure for \(d=30.0 \mathrm{~cm}, 50.0 \mathrm{~cm}, 70.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) and 90.0 cm
(c) Plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm{X}} / \mathrm{N}\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(d / \mathrm{cm}\) ( \(x\)-axis). Start the axes at the origin (0, 0)
Draw a best-fit straight line
<label>[4]
(d) From your graph, determine \(F_{0}\), the value of \(F_{X}\) when \(d=0.0 \mathrm{~cm}\)
Calculate the weight \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre ruler, using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{R}}=2 \times F_{0}\)
(e) State and explain whether your plots made it easy to choose the best-fit line
Justify your answer with reference to your plots
statement
explanation
BLANK PAGE
1 In this experiment, you will investigate a suspended metre ruler and determine the weight of the metre ruler
Refer to Fig. 1.1. Do not change the position of the loops of thread attached to the force meters
(a) (i) Measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}=\)
(ii) Describe one technique for ensuring that this reading is accurate
(b) Pour 200 cm³ of hot water into the beaker
Place the thermometer into the water in the beaker
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t=0\) and immediately start the stop-watch
Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 30 s until \(t=270 \mathrm{~s}\)
(c) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t=0\) and \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
(ii) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the middle 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t=180 \mathrm{~s}\)
(iii) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{3}\) during the last 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) and \(\theta_{270}\) are the temperatures at \(t=180 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t=270 \mathrm{~s}\)
(d) (i) The temperature of the water decreases over time
Use your results from (c) to describe the overall pattern of the rate of cooling of the water in the experiment. Justify your answer by reference to your results
(ii) Estimate the final temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the water after several hours
(e) (i) Another student does the same experiment. She starts with the hot water at a lower initial temperature
Suggest how her cooling rates are likely to compare with yours. Use your results to explain your answer
suggestion
explanation
(ii) State one variable, other than initial water temperature, that the student needs to control
BLANK PAGE
2 In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in a beaker
Refer to Fig. 2.1
(a) (i) Close the switch
Measure, and record in Table 3.1:
· the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across terminals P and Q
· the current \(I\) in the circuit
Open the switch
(ii) Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, resistance \(R\). Use your values of \(V\) and \(I\) and the equation \(R=\frac {V}{I}\)
Circuit B
(b) Disconnect \(R_{2}\) from circuit A. Resistor \(R_{1}\) remains connected between terminals P and Q, as shown in Fig. 3.2
Repeat the procedures in (a)(i) and (a)(ii)
Circuit C
(c) Connect \(R_{2}\) in series with \(R_{1}\) between terminals P and Q, as shown in Fig. 3.3
Repeat the procedures in (a)(i) and (a)(ii)
(d) (i) Calculate resistance \(R_{A}\). Use the value of \(R\) from circuit A and the equation:
Record resistance \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\). \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\) is equal to the value of \(R\) from circuit B

\(
R_{\mathrm{B}}=
\)
Calculate resistance \(R_{\mathrm{C}}\). Use the value of \(R\) from circuit C and the equation:

\(
R_{\mathrm{C}}=
\)
(ii) A student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{A}}, R_{\mathrm{B}}\) and \(R_{\mathrm{C}}\) should all be equal
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement with reference to values from your results
statement
justification
(e) Briefly explain why resistor \(R_{\mathrm{P}}\), shown in Fig. 3.1, must remain in place throughout the experiment
\(R_{\mathrm{P}}\) has a resistance of 3 \(\Omega\). Use your values in Table 3.1 to support your answer
(f) A student determines the resistance of \(R_{1}\). He uses a variable resistor in circuit B to control the current and draws a graph of \(V\) against \(I\)
Briefly explain one advantage of using a variable resistor to control the current
BLANK PAGE
3 In this experiment, you will investigate circuits containing different combinations of resistors
Circuit A has been set up for you
Refer to Fig. 3.1
Resistor \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathrm{p}}\) must remain in place throughout the experiment
Circuit A
4 A student investigates the refraction of light
Refraction is the change in direction of a ray of light when passing into a transparent substance, as shown in Fig. 4.1
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the concentration of a gel affects the angle at which light is refracted when passing from air into the gel
A transparent gel block can be made by dissolving gel powder in hot water in a mould and allowing it to cool. Changing the amount of powder will change the concentration
Concentration is measured in \(\mathrm{g} / \mathrm{cm}^3\)
You are not required to do the experiment
The apparatus available includes:

- samples of gel made at different concentrations and labelled with those concentrations
- a ray-lamp which produces a narrow ray of light
In your plan:
- list any additional apparatus needed
- explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take
- state the key variable to keep constant
- draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
- explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
BLANK PAGE
